page.title: 15NATURE IN SANTON DOWNHAM (3)
page.content: The forest is a good habitat for specialist birds such as the Crossbill. Jays and Tits are common, Woodlarks and Red Backed Shrike have been recorded. The river has Coots, Moorhens, Grebe, Canada Geese etc. and fringe birds such as Linnets, Wagtails and Warblers. Although basically in reserves the Stone Curlew can be found. Game birds such as Pheasant and Red_legged Partridge use the cover and also Golden Pheasant which originally escaped from Elveden. The rotting debris in felled areas makes good habitat for many spiders, other insects and fungi. One fungus, Peniophora Gigantea, is used by the F.C. to treat stumps infected by Fomes.
